October 13, 2013: Fiction
DOCTOR SLEEP, by Stephen King. (Scribner.) Now grown up, Dan, the boy with
psycho-intuitive powers in “The Shining,” helps another threatened child with a
spectacular gift.
THE LONGEST RIDE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central.) The lives of two
couples converge unexpectedly.
THE LOWLAND, by Jhumpa Lahiri. (Knopf.) After his radical brother is killed, an
Indian scientist brings his widow to join him in America.
THE QUEST, by Nelson DeMille. (Center Street.) Two journalists join an elderly
priest who has recently escaped from an Ethiopian jail in a search for a holy relic.
NEVER GO BACK, by Lee Child. (Delacorte.) Jack Reacher is thrown into jail on
trumped-up charges.
W IS FOR WASTED, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam.) A homeless man
inexplicably leaves $600,000 to Kinsey Millhone.
DEADLINE, by Sandra Brown. (Grand Central.) A journalist who pursues a story
about a former marine, the son of terrorists from 40 years ago,becomes a suspect
in the death of his ex-wife.
THANKLESS IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam.) Lt. Eve Dallas searches for a
young man who murdered his parents; by Nora Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
THE FINAL CUT, by Catherine Coulter and J. T. Ellison. (Putnam.) Chief Inspector
Nicholas Drummond of Scotland Yard joins the F.B.I. special agents Lacey Sherlock
and Dillon Savich in a hunt for an international jewel thief in the first volume of a
new series.
INFERNO, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday.) The symbologist Robert Langdon, on the
run in Florence, must decipher a series of codes created by a Dante-loving scientist.
THE CUCKOO'S CALLING, by Robert Galbraith. (Mullholland Books/Little, Brown.)
A detective investigates a suicide; by J.K. Rowling, writing pseudonymously.
AND THE MOUNTAINS ECHOED, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead.) A
multigenerational family saga centers on a brother and sister born in Afghanistan.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown.) A woman disappears on her fifth
anniversary; is her husband a killer?
BLEEDING EDGE, by Thomas Pynchon. (Penguin Press.) A fraud investigator and
Upper West Side mom looks into a suspicious computer security company in 2001.
THE HUSBAND'S SECRET, by Liane Moriarty. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam.) A woman’s
October 13, 2013
Non-Fiction
KILLING JESUS, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt.) Jesus' life and times,
and the events leading up to his execution.
SI-COLOGY 1, by Si Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard Books.) Tales
from Phil’s youngest brother, retired from the Army, who works in the Duck
Commander workshop.
ZEALOT, by Reza Aslan. (Random House.) A biography of Jesus of Nazareth
presents him in the context of his times as the leader of a revolutionary movement.
STILL FOOLIN' 'EM, by Billy Crystal. (Holt.) The 65-year-old comedian’s
reminiscences and his complaints about aging.
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
LIBERTY AMENDMENTS, by Mark R. Levin. (Threshold Editions.) The talk-radio
host offers 11 proposals for returning to America's founding principles.
HAPPY, HAPPY, HAPPY, by Phil Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard
Books.) The Duck Commander pays tribute to “faith, family and ducks.”
EMPTY MANSIONS, by Bill Dedman and Paul Clark Newell Jr.. (Ballantine.) The
eccentric life of the reclusive heiress Huguette Clark, who died at the age of 104 in
SIMPLE DREAMS, by Linda Ronstadt. (Simon & Schuster.) The singer looks back
on her life and career.
COMMAND AND CONTROL, by Eric Schlosser. (Penguin Press.) Accidents and
near misses in the management of America's nuclear arsenal.
AN APPETITE FOR WONDER, by Richard Dawkins. (Ecco/HarperCollins.) A
memoir of the childhood and intellectual development by the evolutionary biologist
(and famous atheist).
FIVE DAYS AT MEMORIAL, by Sheri Fink. (Crown.) The case of a New Orleans
surgeon suspected of euthanizing patients during the Katrina disaster.
WILSON, by A. Scott Berg. (Putnam.) A new biography of the 28th president.
CATASTROPHE 1914, by Max Hastings. (Knopf.) A British historian considers the
first few months of World War I.
REIGN OF ERROR, by Diane Ravitch. (Knopf.) An education scholar denounces
what she claims is an effort by foundations, individual billionaires and hedge fund
managers to destroy public education.
